title: How is it that Russia and the USSR have been such military threats to America with such relatively small economies? - Quora
tags: Russia and the United States of America

response.answer_text: Russia has an economy $1 trillion dollars smaller than the California economy. So it’s a very modest nation, economically-speaking, especially when one considers its population size (about 143 million in Russia vs. 39 million in California) and its land size (about 6.6 million square miles for Russia vs. 163,000 square miles for California). That being said, that’s precisely the reason why the USSR collapsed in the first place—a huge portion of its much smaller GDP (like 15% to 20% at its peak during the Cold War) was funneled to support the military. That stood in stark contrast to the US where, throughout the Cold War, only around 4% to 6% of the US GDP was going to fund the military simply because the US economy was way larger. Such massive military spending squeezed out all other forms of investment in the USSR in the long run—especially for consumer goods and housing for most Soviet citizens. This led to widespread discontent among the Soviet citizenry, and mortally ate away at the legitimacy of the Communist Party. It also led to all sorts of enormous economic distortions, which slowed down and then stagnated the USSR economy in the 1970s and 1980s. Suffice to say, if the USSR had had a much bigger economy to support its huge military expenditures, there’s no doubt that it would still be around. Nowadays the Russian economy is even smaller than the USSR economy (partly because the USSR had 250 million people and Russia now only has 143 million people). If it seeks to project military power in the way the USSR did back in the day, Russia would have to more or less devote 25% to 35% of its GDP to military expenditure. This would drive out all other sorts of investment from the economy, further impoverishing normal Russian citizens as there would be no resources left for consumer goods and housing. (This is precisely what happens in North Korea, where roughly 30% of the GDP is spent on the military, leaving average North Koreans dirt poor.) This, in turn, would lead to so much mass unrest that Putin would probably be toppled through a very bloody rebellion. So, in the long run Russia will still lose to the US—because its economy is much smaller and weaker. And before anyone says that having a huge nuclear arsenal makes Russia strong—one must remember that most of its nuclear weapons are strictly defensive in nature. In other words, the only way Russia can use its nuclear weapons is if it is attacked first and with nuclear weapons. It cannot project power outside its borders with nuclear weapons alone. Otherwise, if Russia opts to utilize atomic bombs in offensive measures—like in a small war—it is likely to invite massive retaliation from the Western nuclear powers—the US, the UK and France. So Russia would rather not do this, for obvious reasons.

“We’re hearing a lot about a possible new cold war on the horizon these days with how Russia was speaking about a possible Clinton administration and Obama putting troops in Eastern Europe, but I was looking at country ranks by total GDP and Russia is below even Italy and Canada.” Yes…. current Russia. Currently Russia has a smaller economy than California in terms of nominal GDP. Current Russia does not equal the USSR. The USSR had one of the largest economies on earth. At the end of WWII the USSR had an economy about 30% the size of the US, but it grew faster than the US economy for the next few decades. In 1975 the USSR was 57% the economy of the US. https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/DOC_0000497165.pdf After then however, they and their Warsaw Pact allies ran into serious problems, to say the least. That segues into my next point: the USSR had a bunch of puppet-state allies. Their loyalty is dubious in hindsight (I mean… the Romanian Army shot the Soviet-backed dictator as soon as the wall came down and government after government fell to civil unrest), but on paper at least, they had about 350,000,000 people in their sphere of influence. In 1949 about 1/3 of the world’s population, or 800,000,000 people, lived in the Soviet sphere of influence (prior to the Sino-Soviet split). That is a large reason of how the USSR was threatening. At the end of WWII, they had troops all over Europe and Central Asia and occupied dozens of countries. In most of those countries they installed a government that would support Soviet interests.

GDP may not be the best measure here. It’s not only about how much money you have or create, but also how you spend it. I’ll give you an example. At the end of the 1980s, Poland was still part of the Warsaw Pact. A country of around 35 million people (around 15% of the US population) had an army of almost 350,000 soldiers (with reserves going in millions, being that army service was compulsory for all men above the age of 18), with over 3,300 tanks, 4,800 armored vehicles and 480 F&A planes. That was just one Poland, whose army’s target in case of WW3 was taking over Denmark. The total forces of the Warsaw Pact included over 3.5 million soldiers in active duty, almost 60k tanks and over 70k armored vehicles. Now, they may not have been the most modern models, but the sheer numbers are scary. On top of that, many countries of the Warsaw Pact had tactical nuclear weapons deployed on their territories; the scary thing about it was, that Russians were thought to be crazy enough to actually use them. You can top it with the fact, that for the longest time after WW2, Russians had an advantage over the US with regard to their space program. They were the first ones to place a satellite above the Earth, first to shoot a man into space, and first ones to develop a successful ICBM. And again, they were thought to be crazy enough to actually use them. In the end, the small economy vs. large military spending turned out bad for the Soviet Bloc and resulted with its fall. But at least for some time there, in posed a real threat. If not to the US directly, then surely for Western Europe.

I would say that, given historical and current context, military presence isn’t tightly coupled to economic size. Countries can afford to invest disproportionate amounts of money in their military (at least in the short term), and sometimes the military of a country can be more efficient than other countries. For a good example of strong investment, see North Korea, which has a weak economy but a relevant military on the global stage. For a good example of efficient military, see the history of Great Britain’s navy, which has held off significantly larger and better-funded forces repeatedly. Over-investment in military might with a weak economy can lead to instability in the long-term though. North Korea is in a shambles, and the cold war ended when the USSR collapsed.
